com.pb.sawdust.util.format

Class TextFormat

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.util.format.TextFormat

  • public class TextFormat
extends java.lang.Object
    The TextFormat class provides a structured class representation of the string formatting syntax used by the java.util.Formatter class. The intention of the class is to provide greater transparency to formats, to provide a safe structure through which formats can be reused, and to move formatting (syntax) errors from formatting calls to format definitions.

    Text formats provide a standard through which various inputs (objects or primitives) are printed to text. Each format is defined by a TextFormat.Conversion, which defines, generally, how a given input is converted to text. Formats can contain a (positive integer) width, which specifies the minimum number of characters the text output must contain (in cases where the output is too small, the text will be padded with spaces). Some formats may contain a precision, which indicates either a numerical precision or a maximum number of characters in the text output. In addition, a given format can contain TextFormat.FormatFlags, which offer modifications to how the output is formatted. Also, the TextFormat.Conversion.DATE_TIME and TextFormat.Conversion.DATE_TIME_UPPER_CASE take an additional TextFormat.DateTimeConversion to further specify the date/time output formatting. For more information on the specifics of formatting, the user should reference the Formatter documentation, cross-referencing with the enums contained in this class (all text format combinations/possibilities can be created using these constructs).

    To use the formats contained in this class, the toString() and getFormat* methods to get format strings which can be used directly in format calls. For example, for formats f1 and f2, a formatted text output can be created through the following call: 

    
     System.out.printf("Object 2: " + f2.getFormat(2) + ", object1: " + f1.getFormat(1) ,object1,object2);

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  TextFormat.Conversion
      The Conversion enum defines all of the possible text format conversions available to TextFormat instances.
      static class  TextFormat.DateTimeConversion
      The DateTimeConversion enum defines all of the date time conversions available to TextFormat instances with the conversion TextFormat.Conversion.DATE_TIME or TextFormat.Conversion.DATE_TIME_UPPER_CASE.
      static class  TextFormat.FormatFlag
      The FormatFlag enum represents every text format flag available to TextFormat instances.

      The TextFormat used for a percent character.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TextFormat

        public TextFormat(TextFormat.Conversion conversion,
          int minimumWidth,
          int precision,
          TextFormat.FormatFlag... flags)
        Format constructor specifying conversion, width, precision, and flags.
        Parameters:
        conversion - The conversion for this text format.
        minimumWidth - The minimum width for this text format.
        precision - The precision for this text format.
        flags - The flags for this text format.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if width or precision is less than one; if conversion is DATE_TIME or DATE_TIME_UPPER_CASE (use constructors taking an explicit DateTimeConversion); or if flags and/or precision cannot be used with the specified conversion.

      • getMinimumWidthFormat

        public static TextFormat getMinimumWidthFormat(TextFormat format,
                               int minimumWidth)
        Get a text format that replicates a given text format except it changes (or adds) a minimum width.
        Parameters:
        format - The input format to replicate.
        minimumWidth - The minimimum width for the output format.
        Returns:
        a text format which replicates format and has width minimumWidth.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if minimumWidth is less than one.

      • getPrecisionFormat

        public static TextFormat getPrecisionFormat(TextFormat format,
                            int precision)
        Get a text format that replicates a given text format except it changes (or adds) a precision.
        Parameters:
        format - The input format to replicate.
        precision - The precision for the output format.
        Returns:
        a text format which replicates format and has precision precision.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if precisiuon is less than one, or if format does not allow a precision.

      • getPrecisionFormat

        public static TextFormat getPrecisionFormat(TextFormat.Conversion conversion,
                            int precision,
                            TextFormat.FormatFlag... flags)
        Get a text format with a specified precision but no specified minimum width.
        Parameters:
        conversion - The conversion for the text format.
        precision - The precision for the text format.
        flags - The flags for the text format.
        Returns:
        the text format with specified conversion, precision, and flags.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if @code precision} is less than one, or if flags and/or precision cannot be used with the specified conversion.

        Parameters:

        flags - The flags for the output format.
        Returns:

        Throws:

        Returns:

      • isValidArgument

        public boolean isValidArgument(java.lang.Object argument)
        Determine whether a given input is a valid argument for this format. i.e., whether or not a call to a formatting method using argument (e.g. System.out.printf(format,argument)) will throw an exception due to an invalid argument or not.
        Parameters:
        argument - The argument whose validity is being checked.
        Returns:
        true if the argument can be used with this format, false otherwise.
